document_title: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): Symptoms and causes
subsection_content:
Women are diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder twice as often as men. In addition, the following subjects are susceptible to generalized anxiety disorder [3]:
Personality: people with a shy, negative or avoidant temperament are more susceptible to generalized anxiety disorder than others; Genetics: generalized anxiety disorder can run in families; Family history: people with generalized anxiety disorder have experienced traumatic, negative events in childhood or recently. In addition, chronic medical illnesses or other mental health disorders can also increase the risk.
When the following signs appear, the patient should see a doctor or psychologist:
Feel like you're worrying too much and it's affecting your work, relationships, or other aspects of your life.; Feeling depressed, irritable or having other mental health concerns; Having suicidal thoughts or behavior: this case requires immediate treatment.
Anxiety is unlikely to go away on its own, and may even become serious over time. Try to seek help from a doctor or psychologist before your anxiety becomes severe. Early treatment can quickly improve this condition.
